author: Stevie24
text: Can anyone tell me how can I extract & delete from file1, the lines containing specific strings, and move them to a new file named file2 ? the string is dynamic; example : I'm interested to extract all lines containing DOG, 192168, IL. All 3 are separate patterns. Thanks in advance.

author: skrrp
text: Guest7100: install BSD. joking aside there are many small and big things you can do to secure your system. start with sshd_config. move the ssh port to a high number in the user range, disable root login. use nmap to scan your system for open ports (services). disable any you don't need. kill inetd if it's running. kill any insecure ftp programs. you might consider a firewall (shorewall) or...

author: skrrp
text: ...selinux. you could opt for just not having ports open rather than firewalls. read up on port knocking if you are truly paranoid

author: histo
text: Stevie24: you could one liner it with a ;

author: Stevie24
text: ah, ok

author: histo
text: Stevie24: grep searchterm somefile > newfile ; sed -ie 's/searchterm//g' somefile

text: But isn't that impossible, since I have 24 separate strings ?

author: Stevie24
text: That would mean 24 x grep + 24 x sed. Am I wrong?

author: SpecialEd
text: Hello, I am looking for a real time cpu/ram/bandwidth monitor for 6 remote servers that will display on a single web page. Currently I have SSH sessions into my servers with htop and bwm-ng running. Does anyone know a good way to do this via the web? I have tried munin and nagios and I don't believe they really show real time (their real time is 1 min refresh)

author: histo
text: Stevie24: you can do multiple patterns

author: holstein
text: nagios is an industry standard

author: SpecialEd
text: holstein: I agree, but is there a way to make it work so it shows like 1 second refresh ?

author: SpecialEd
text: for 6 servers?

author: SpecialEd
text: If so then Ill head over to #nagios

author: holstein
text: Stevie24: im just saying, if nagios didnt do what i wanted, id rethink what i want.. probably not necessary to have a 1 second refresh

author: SpecialEd
text: holstein: servers run development operations and i'd like to be able to spot spikes

author: SpecialEd
text: holstein: therefore 1 minute refresh won't likely show spikes...

author: histo
text: Stevie24 both grep and sed can use the -e for_pattern  so grep -i -e pattern1 -e pattern2 > somefile  sed -i -e 's/pattern1//g' -e 's/pattern2//g'

author: Stevie24
text: Great histo, thank you so much !!

author: marscher
text: histo, thanks for all this information, but I currently noticed, that I cant perform any of them in my current environment, since I've mounted an btrfs image, which shares the same uuid like an already mounted volume....

author: marscher
text: and it seems, there is no way around this.

author: marscher
text: so I guess I first have to transfer all files from the backup image to another filesystem (which is superstupid... :()

author: histo
text: marscher: can't you mount by label?

author: marscher
text: histo, my research so far results, that the uuid is stored inherently in the filesystem(image)

author: marscher
text: and is not changeable

author: histo
text: marscher: how do you have matching uuid's what are you trying to do?

author: marscher
text: so how would a label change that?

author: marscher
text: trying to mount an image of my currently running system on a loopback device

author: histo
text: marscher: ahh

author: marscher
text: but because those uuids are the same (image and source), the mounted image shows exactly the same contents like current

author: marscher
text: funy :D

author: boolean
text: morning .. is iptables a 1st match style firewall?

author: histo
text: boolean: 1st match?

author: ActionParsnip
text: histo: when a rule is matched, no others are processed

author: histo
text: ahh

author: boolean
text: ActionParsnip: beat me to it :) thanks

author: ActionParsnip
text: boolean: usually traffic will only satisfy one rule, otherwise you should have a deny all rule at the bottom that the rest will hit and be denied
